{{Infobox military person |name = Diana M. Holland |birth_date = |death_date = |birth_place = |death_place = |image = Brigadier General Diana M. Holland.jpg |allegiance = {{nowrap|{{flag|United States of America}}}} |branch = {{nowrap|{{army|USA}}}} |serviceyears = 1990–Present |rank = [[File:US-O7 insignia.svg|24px]] [[Brigadier General (United States)|Brigadier General]] |commands = [[92nd Engineer Battalion]]
[[130th Engineer Brigade (United States)|130th Engineer Brigade]] |battles = [[Iraq War]]
[[Operation Enduring Freedom]]
[[Operation Freedom's Sentinel]]
[[Operation Resolute Support]] |awards = [[Legion of Merit]] with two [[oak leaf cluster]]s
[[Bronze Star Medal]] with two oak leaf clusters
[[Defense Meritorious Service Medal]]
[[Meritorious Service Medal (United States)|Meritorious Service Medal]] with four oak leaf clusters
[[Combat Action Badge]]
[[Senior Parachutist Badge]]
[[German Parachutist Badge]]
Silver Order of the [[de Fleury Medal]] }} [[File:Brigadier General Diana Holland, July 29, 2015.JPG|thumb|Brig. Gen. Diana Holland becomes the first woman to hold the title of deputy commanding general for support in a light infantry division during her promotion ceremony to brigadier on Fort Drum, N.Y., July 29, 2015. Her husband, James Holland Jr., right, and Army Maj. Gen. Jeffrey L. Bannister, 10th Mountain Division and Fort Drum commander, pin on her stars]] '''Diana M. Holland''' (née '''Leach'''){{cite news|last1=Keating|first1=Susan|title=General Diana Holland Will Become West Point's First Female Commandant of Cadets|url=http://www.people.com/article/diana-holland-named-west-point-first-female-commandant-cadets|accessdate=December 28, 2015|work=People|date=December 16, 2015}} is an American military officer and a [[Brigadier general (United States)|brigadier general]] in the [[United States Army]]. A veteran of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, the Army announced her as the first female [[commandant of cadets]] at the [[United States Military Academy]] in December 2015. ==Early life and education== When she was six years old, Holland, the [[Santa Barbara, California]] native and daughter of a [[United States Marine Corps|United States Marine]], was inspired to join the military by her grandfather’s military service.{{cite news|last1=Block|first1=Gordon|title=Fort Drum’s first-ever female deputy commanding general embraces new role|url=http://www.watertowndailytimes.com/news03/fort-drums-first-ever-female-deputy-commanding-general-embraces-new-role-20150730|accessdate=December 21, 2015|work=Watertown Daily Times|date=July 30, 2015}} She attended the United States Military Academy from 1986-1990. While at West Point, she played [[Women's lacrosse|lacrosse]] and was co-captain her senior year. Following graduation, she was commissioned a [[Second_lieutenant#United_States|Second Lieutenant]] in the [[United States Army Corps of Engineers]]. ==Career== After commissioning, Holland first served in Germany as a vertical construction platoon leader in the 79th Engineer Combat Battalion (Heavy), and as a company executive officer and battalion assistant operations officer in the 94th Engineer Combat Battalion (Heavy). Upon returning to the United States, Holland was assigned to the 30th Engineer Battalion (Topographic), [[20th Engineer Brigade (United States)|20th Engineer Brigade]], at [[Fort Bragg]], [[North Carolina]] and served as the battalion logistics officer and then as the commander of Headquarters and Headquarters Company.{{cite news|last1=ARNEWS/USMA|title=Holland named first woman commandant at West Point|url=http://www.army.mil/article/159993/Holland_named_first_woman_commandant_at_West_Point/|accessdate=December 21, 2015|agency=Army News Service|date=December 15, 2015}} Following company command, Holland earned a [[Master of Arts]] degree at [[Duke University]] en route to a teaching assignment at the United States Military Academy, where she served as a faculty member in the history department from 1999 until 2002.{{cite news|last1=Fort Drum Public Affairs Office|title=Fort Drum announces 10th Mountain command changes|url=http://www.drum.army.mil/mountaineer/Article.aspx?ID=9692|accessdate=December 21, 2015|work=The Mountaineer Online|date=December 17, 2015}} She then attended the [[United States Army Command and General Staff College|Army Command and General Staff College]] and the [[School of Advanced Military Studies]] (SAMS) where she earned a Master of Military Arts and Sciences degree. In July 2004, she was assigned to the [[3rd Infantry Division (United States)|3rd Infantry Division]] and deployed to [[Iraq War|Operation Iraqi Freedom]], serving as a division plans officer and then as the operations officer in the [[92nd Engineer Battalion|92nd Engineer Combat Battalion]] (Heavy). Returning from Iraq, she then served as a plans officer in the Operations Directorate, [[United States Central Command]] at [[MacDill Air Force Base]] in [[Tampa, Florida]]. Holland then returned to command the 92nd Engineer Battalion (Black Diamonds) from July 2008 to June 2011, which included deploying with "Task Force Diamond" to eastern Afghanistan from May 2010 to April 2011. After relinquishing command, she became a [[United States Army War College]] [[Fellow]] at [[Georgetown University]]. In 2012, BG Holland assumed command of the [[130th Engineer Brigade]] at [[Schofield Barracks]], [[Hawaii]]. The following year, she deployed with the Brigade Headquarters to [[Bagram Airfield]], Afghanistan where the unit served as the Theater Engineer Brigade, Joint Task Force Sapper. The Brigade redeployed to Schofield Barracks in June 2014, where Holland relinquished command in July. In the first half of 2015, she served as executive officer to the [[United_States_Department_of_the_Army#The_Army_Staff|Director of the Army Staff]] at [[the Pentagon]]. In late July 2015, Holland was assigned as the Deputy Commanding General for Support, [[10th Mountain Division|10th Mountain Division (Light Infantry)]] at [[Fort Drum, New York]], where she deployed again to Afghanistan in support of [[Operation Freedom's Sentinel]] and [[Operation Resolute Support]].{{cite news|last1=Ayyad|first1=Osama|title=Face of Defense: 10th Mountain Gets First Female Brigadier General|url=http://www.defense.gov/News-Article-View/Article/614056/face-of-defense-10th-mountain-gets-first-female-brigadier|accessdate=December 21, 2015|agency=U. S. Department of Defense|date=August 19, 2015}} Upon assignment there, she became the first woman to serve as a general officer at Fort Drum, and the first woman to serve as a deputy commanding general in one of the Army's light infantry divisions.{{cite news|last1=Weiner|first1=Mark|title=Fort Drum marks promotion of first woman general of 10th Mountain Division|url=http://www.syracuse.com/state/index.ssf/2015/07/fort_drum_marks_promotion_of_first_woman_general_of_10th_mountain_division.html|accessdate=December 21, 2015|work=The Post-Standard|agency=Syracuse Media Group|date=July 30, 2015}} On 15 December 2015, she was announced as the 76th [[commandant of cadets|commandant of the Corps of Cadets]] at West Point, the first female to serve in that role.{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/military/west-point-names-diana-holland-first-woman-commandant-cadets-n480906|title=West Point Names Diana Holland as First Woman Commandant of Cadets|author=Alastair Jamieson|accessdate=December 21, 2015|work=NBC News|date=December 16, 2015}} ==Awards== Brigadier General Holland’s awards and decorations include the [[Legion of Merit]] with two [[oak leaf cluster]]s, the [[Bronze Star Medal]] with two oak leaf clusters, the [[Defense Meritorious Service Medal]], the [[Meritorious Service Medal (United States)|Meritorious Service Medal]] with four oak leaf clusters, the [[Combat Action Badge]], the [[Senior Parachutist Badge]], the [[German Parachutist Badge]], and the Silver Order of the [[de Fleury Medal]]. ==Personal life== General Holland is married to James Holland, Jr., a 20-year Army veteran, and has two children and four grandchildren. ==References== {{Include-USGov|agency=U.S. Department of Defense}} {{reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Holland, Diana M.}} [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Female generals of the United States Army]] [[Category:United States Military Academy alumni]] [[Category:Commandants of the Corps of Cadets of the United States Military Academy]] [[Category:Recipients of the Legion of Merit]] [[Category:Recipients of the Bronze Star Medal]]
